ScanSettings.Setting: Search Starting from Entry Points, Search Starting of Public and Protected Methods

Glossary.Type:
A web application can use user input to generate a path to a file included into server response. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can obtain an arbitrary file content for example script source code or configuration file.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['file'])) {
    $file = 'downloads/' . $_GET['file'];
    if (file_exists($file))
        readfile($file);
}

With combination of "../", it is possible to traverse folders and access a file located outside web server root folder. The figure gives the attack results targeted /etc/passwd file:

Figure 1. Arbitrary Files Reading example

Recommendations

We recommend you to validate data via regular expressions that restrict arbitrary files reading or use file white lists. We also recommend executing application code in isolated environment.

Links

  • CWE-73: External Control of File Name or Path http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/73.html

A web application is vulnerable if it places data from an untrusted source without sufficient processing into a web server response. An attacker can conduct this attack to execute a malware script in a target domain's context. As a rule, the malware code sends user sensitive data to the attacker, for example user session ID.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['name'])) {
    echo "{$_GET['name']}!\n";
}

An attacker can make a user to go to this link http://test.loc/test.php?name=%3Cscript%3Ealert. The following code is injected into web server response: <script>alert('XSS')<script>. The results are given on the figure:

Figure 1. An attack example

Web application can be vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting not only in HTTP response data displaying, but also in displaying results of database queries, file content, etc.

Recommendations

To eliminate the vulnerability, escape special characters depending on the data context.

Links

  • Cross-site Scripting (XSS) https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)
  • CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/79.html

The setting defines HTTP status code that make a receiver to redirect users to a certain URL. So, the setting configures error pages for different HTTP status codes. The recommended range of values if 400-414, 500, 502-504.

Type.DisplayName: Exposure of System Data to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
Type.TypeName: Exposure of System Data to an Unauthorized Control Sphere

Glossary.Type: Exposing system data or debugging information helps an adversary learn about the system and form an attack plan.
The setting defines httpOnly flag for Set-Cookie HTTP header that restricts Cookie data reading/writing via JavaScript.
The setting defines secure flag for Set-Cookie HTTP header that defines if cookie are sent via secure connections only (https).
The setting defines session lifetime in minutes.

A web application can generate SQL queries based on user input data. Because of insufficient data processing, an attacker can inject SQL code and thus modify database query logic. In certain cases, an attacker is able not only read data from a database, but also read arbitrary files, create new files, conduct denial of service, and even get web application source codes, upload and execute malware code.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->query("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id=" . $_GET['id']);
    $user = $stm->fetch();
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

An attacker can obtain arbitrary data, for example database version, sending the following line in id parameter: 0+union+select+1,version().

Figure 1. SQL Injection example

Recommendations

We recommend you to convert variables to integer type to protect against SQL Injection attacks.

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->query("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id=" . (int)$_GET['id']);
    $user = $stm->fetch();
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

A good idea is to use parametrized SQL queries instead of simple concatenation of variables and query templates in application code.

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->prepare("SELECT name FROM users WHERE id=?");
    $stm->execute(array($_GET['id']));
    $user = $stm->fetch(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

It is also required to use the principle of minimal privilege to guarantee that an account aimed to web application interaction with a database has minimal privileges and all other privileges are not available.

Links

  • SQL Injection https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection
  • CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/89.html
Debug pages or messages, error descriptions, stack tracing, etc. in productive systems allows attackers to obtain information about application internals that is useful for conducting attacks.
The setting defines if a session ID (JSESSIONID) is sent as a URL parameter or is stored in user Cookie.
The setting defines if encrypted SSL connections are used for data transferring.

• CVE-2011-4969 Cross-site Scripting - Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in jQuery before 2.0.3, when using location.hash.slice to select elements, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a crafted tag.
  • CVE-2011-4969 Cross-site Scripting - Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in jQuery, when using location.hash and jquery-migrate in one page, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a crafted tag.
  • CVE-2011-4969 Cross-site Scripting - Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in jQuery, when using (class selector).hash and jquery-migrate in one page, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a crafted tag.

Vulnerable hashing functions in your application can lead to predictable hash collisions or hash reverse attacks. Cryptographic hashing guarantee that hash collisions are unlikely, and hash reversing is difficult to conduct.

PCIDSS.DisplayName: Using strong cryptography, render all authentication credentials (such as passwords/phrases) unreadable during transmission and storage on all system components

Nist.DisplayName: Identification and Authentication Policy and Procedures

Vulnerability.AdditionalConditions: (((javax.sql.DataSource) ((javax.naming.Context) new javax.naming.InitialContext().lookup("java:comp/env")).lookup("jdbc/app01/DB")).getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery("SELECT CONCAT (cname2, ' ', cname1) AS cname FROM pt.employee WHERE cname2 = '" + theRq.getParameter("NAME") + "'").getString("cname") == "<script>alert(1)</script>" || ((javax.sql.DataSource) ((javax.naming.Context) new javax.naming.InitialContext().lookup("java:comp/env")).lookup("jdbc/app01/DB")).getConnection().prepareStatement("SELECT CONCAT (cname2, ' ', cname1) AS cname FROM pt.employee WHERE cname2 = ?").executeQuery().getString("cname") == "<script>alert(1)</script>")
Vulnerability.TrimmedAdditionalConditions: (((javax.sql.DataSource) ((javax.naming.Context) new javax.naming.InitialContext().lookup("java:comp/env")).lookup("jdbc/app01/DB")).getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery("SELECT CONCAT (cname2, ' ', cname1) AS cname FROM pt.employee WHERE cname2 = '" + theRq.getParameter("NAME") + "'").getString("cname") == "<script>alert(1)</script>" || ((javax.sql.DataSource) ((javax.naming.Context) new javax.naming.InitialContext().lookup("java:comp/env")).lookup("jdbc/app01/DB")).getConnection().prepareStatement("SELECT CONCAT (cname2, ' ', cname1) AS cname FROM pt.employee WHERE cname2 = ?").executeQuery().getString("cname") == "<script>alert(1)</script>")
